body:
ðŸ‘ from me on this. Having separate types in `@types/*` packages is a common source of confusion &/| inconvenience on the TypeScript/types side. The standard DefinitelyTyped recommendation is to bundle types in packages when the package is _"written in TypeScript"[^1]_ - but I think that that phrasing should probably be updated to _"has its own type definitions"_.

Once ESLint has its own types, `@types/eslint` can become a "stub" package. DefinitelyTyped has built-in support for removing packages[^2].

One cautionary note is that changing types layouts -even moving from DT to a first-party plugin- can impact a lot of downstream repos in surprising ways. I'd suggest trying the PR that resolves this issue on a few community ESLint configs & plugins that use `@types/eslint`.

[^1]: https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped?tab=readme-ov-file#create-a-new-package
[^2]: https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped?tab=readme-ov-file#removing-a-package

> One cautionary note is that changing types layouts -even moving from DT to a first-party plugin- can impact a lot of downstream repos in surprising ways. I'd suggest trying the PR that resolves this issue on a few community ESLint configs & plugins that use `@types/eslint`.

Definitely we should do that. From what I can tell, TypeScript seems to prefer bundled types over types provided by external packages. This means that as soon as ESLint will include its own types, the types in `@types/eslint` will be ignored by the tsc compiler. I'm not sure if there will be a way to revert to using `@types/eslint` for projects that need those types for compatibility, but even so, that will require changing the TS config.

Thanks for the insights @JoshuaKGoldberg, those are very helpful.

And agree, we should definitely test with some downstream packages. Hopefully by starting out with the same type definitions, we'll minimize any disturbance.

A complicating factor:
https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/tree/master/types/eslint/rules

These look to be about three years out-of-date, so I wonder if it would be safe to just drop them at this point.

That would be awesome. I'd like to add that working with DefinitelyTyped is a very unpleasing process because of the tremendous (and growing) size of the repository that slaughters basically every computer I've used to provide some fixes there. I'm not ashamed to say that I stopped maintaining some types there because working on the repository is a pain. So, having the types maintained here would also, in my opinion, make their maintenance way easier and community-friendly.

> A complicating factor: https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/tree/master/types/eslint/rules
 
I think part of those types could be autogenerated from rule `meta.schema` arrays, but there will be discrepancies.

@fasttime they could be, but it seems like that would take a lot of time to verify.

To move forward here, there are two paths:

1. Include those files as-is without worrying about whether or not they are up to date
2. Don't include them as just export `ESLintRules` as:

```ts
export interface ESLintRules
    extends
        Linter.RulesRecord
{}
```

issue.body:
<!--
    Thank you for contributing!

    ESLint adheres to the [OpenJS Foundation Code of Conduct](https://eslint.org/conduct).
-->

#### Prerequisites checklist

- [x] I have read the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/eslint/eslint/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md).

#### What is the purpose of this pull request? (put an "X" next to an item)

<!--
    The following template is intentionally not a markdown checkbox list for the reasons
    explained in https://github.com/eslint/eslint/pull/12848#issuecomment-580302888
-->

[ ] Documentation update
[ ] Bug fix ([template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eslint/eslint/HEAD/templates/bug-report.md))
[ ] New rule ([template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eslint/eslint/HEAD/templates/rule-proposal.md))
[ ] Changes an existing rule ([template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eslint/eslint/HEAD/templates/rule-change-proposal.md))
[ ] Add autofix to a rule
[ ] Add a CLI option
[x] Add something to the core
[ ] Other, please explain:

<!--
    If the item you've checked above has a template, please paste the template questions below and answer them. (If this pull request is addressing an issue, you can just paste a link to the issue here instead.)
-->

<!--
    Please ensure your pull request is ready:

    - Read the pull request guide (https://eslint.org/docs/latest/contribute/pull-requests)
    - Include tests for this change
    - Update documentation for this change (if appropriate)
-->

<!--
    The following is required for all pull requests:
-->

#### What changes did you make? (Give an overview)

Added the type definitions from `@types/eslint` to the project:

- Added all type definitions in `lib/types`
- Added tests in `tests/lib/types`
- Added new `test:types` script to run type checking tests
- Added `npm run test:types` to CI to be run on each PR
- Added `types` entries to `package.json`

For simplicity, I did not enable type checking for the whole repo, just for the type tests.

This is intended to be a base for us to build off of. We can look to make improvements in future PRs.

fixes #18845

#### Is there anything you'd like reviewers to focus on?

The types are copied over as-is without modification (aside from including the license). We don't need to review their contents right now.

Does the testing setup make sense?


<!-- markdownlint-disable-file MD004 -->

issue.title: External: Mark @types/eslint as a stub types package

labels.name: accepted
labels.description: There is consensus among the team that this change meets the criteria for inclusion

repository.name: eslint
repository.description: Find and fix problems in your JavaScript code.

issue.body:
Following #18845 -> https://github.com/eslint/eslint/issues/18845#issuecomment-2325259204 -> #18854 -> https://github.com/eslint/rewrite/pull/106#discussion_r1769036084: now that ESLint publishes its own `.d.ts` TypeScript types, there are two packages consumers can pull ESLint from:

* [`eslint`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/eslint) itself: which is now the correct place
* [`@types/eslint`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@types/eslint), as published by https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/tree/master/types/eslint: which is now slightly outdated

Once a package publishes its own types, it's common practice for the DefinitelyTyped side to mark the the old `@types/` package as a "stub" (no-longer-necessary) package. From https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped?tab=readme-ov-file#removing-a-package:


> When a package [bundles](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/declaration-files/publishing.html) its own types, types should be removed from Definitely Typed to avoid confusion.
> 
> You can remove it by running `pnpm run not-needed <typingsPackageName> <asOfVersion> [<libraryName>]`.
> 
> - `<typingsPackageName>`: This is the name of the directory to delete.
> - `<asOfVersion>`: A stub will be published to `@types/<typingsPackageName>` with this version. Should be higher than any currently published version and should be a version of `<libraryName>` on npm.
> - `<libraryName>`: Name of npm package that replaces the Definitely Typed types. Usually this is identical to `<typingsPackageName>`, in which case you can omit it.

https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/pull/70012 is a good example of another package that was migrated to TypeScript. [`@types/react-datepicker`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@types/react-datepicker) now has no `.d.ts` files in it. The package instead has an npm deprecation:

> This is a stub types definition. react-datepicker provides its own type definitions, so you do not need this installed.

Is there anything blocking an enterprising individual from sending a similar PR to DefinitelyTyped to deprecate `@types/eslint`?

issue.title: Change Request: Add per-rule types

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: This change enhances an existing feature of ESLint

labels.name: core
labels.description: Relates to ESLint's core APIs and features

labels.name: accepted
labels.description: There is consensus among the team that this change meets the criteria for inclusion

repository.name: eslint
repository.description: Find and fix problems in your JavaScript code.

issue.body:
### ESLint version

9.26.0

### What problem do you want to solve?

ESLint now has first-class types (#18845) which is awesome, but there is still room for improvement, especially regarding autocomplete/intellisense. This is due to the default type for `Config.rules` just being:

https://github.com/eslint/eslint/blob/f60f2764971a33e252be13e560dccf21f554dbf1/lib/types/index.d.ts#L1384-L1386

This is functional, and does provide type-safety and autocomplete around the rule severity, but it does not provide safety/autocomplete around the rules used or their options.

My main complaint is that the `rules` object and rule options have no autocomplete out-of-the-box. This makes it slightly more annoying to try to write rules quickly as I have to reference external documentation rather than bringing up autocomplete and reading through the results.

Relatedly, built-in rules' options have no type safety. This means that typos in rule configs are not caught by TS, even though they totally could be. For example, currently this snippet will pass type checks:

```ts
export default defineConfig({
  rules: {
    // Typo! "nax" instead of "max"
    complexity: ["error", { nax: 2 }],
    // Typo! Used a string instead of a number
    "max-params": ["error", { max: '2' }]
  },
});
```

### What do you think is the correct solution?

I would like the default definition of `RulesRecord` that ESLint ships with to contain type definitions for all the first-party rules and their options out-of-the-box. I'm no ESLint expert, but as far as I can tell all the information needed to generate these types already exists in machine-readable formats, so unless I'm missing something it should be as "simple" as adding a script / build step that auto-generates the rules definitions.

### Participation

- [x] I am willing to submit a pull request for this change.

### Additional comments

This would also allow for clearer signaling of deprecated options (e.g. the `maximum` form of `max-params`) by adding the `@deprecated` tag to the documentation for that option.

Finally, it would be extra useful if these type definitions would also contain the documentation for the rule / option in question so we can easily read up on what a particular rule or option does without needing to go to the full website documentation. This is a stretch goal however, and would likely require a not-insignificant amount of extra work, so I understand if it is put off / axed. If injecting the full text of the rule's / option's documentation is too much I would settle for a link directly to the documentation.
